text:
Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the dangers of sharing information online. The website said that if you share information about yourself online, it can be seen by people you don't know. This made people think about the downsides of sharing information on the internet.
There are a lot of new opportunities to share information online. You can share photos, stories, and personal information. But you should be careful because the water in the digital world is crowded and treacherous.
In the early days of the internet, there were people who started sharing their lives online. They called themselves bloggers. They wrote about their experiences, their thoughts, and their feelings. Some people liked what they wrote, but others didn't.
One day, a woman named Heather Armstrong was writing a blog about her job. An anonymous person sent the address of her blog to her boss. As a result, she lost her job. This is called the 'online distribution effect'.
We can all learn from Heather Armstrong's story. If you share information online, you should be careful about what you say. The internet is a powerful tool, but it can also be dangerous.

A long time ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know? which showed that there is a lot about the universe that we don’t understand. The movie was very interesting, but it didn’t have much evidence to support its claims. Some people thought that the movie was dangerous and should not be seen. Others thought that it was a must-see movie. I couldn’t see what all the fuss was about at first, but when the movie moved on to describe some of the discoveries, I started to see what the fuss was really about. One of the discoveries was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. This is a very amazing claim, but it doesn’t have much evidence to support it. Before we get too excited, we need to have some decent proof that the effect is real. The movie’s claims were not bizarre enough. They were too easy to believe. If the movie had made more outrageous claims, it would have been more interesting.

I find writing novels a challenge, and writing short stories a joy. Writing novels is like planting a forest, and writing short stories is more like planting a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape that I treasure.
I write short stories because they are quick and easy to write. It generally takes me about a week to get a short story into some kind of decent shape. You can create a story out of the smallest things, and you don’t have to worry about failing.
My short stories are like soft shadows I have set out in the world, faint footprints I have left behind. I remember exactly where I set down each and every one of them, and how I felt when I did. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy as a writer to be able to share these intimate feelings with my readers.

Science is a powerful force that has improved our lives and threatened our existence. It has made it easier for us to understand the world around us and has also led to many new inventions. Science has also been used to treat diseases and to help us learn more about ourselves.
Science is not always easy to understand. Sometimes scientists disagree with each other about the best way to explain things. But even when scientists disagree, they are still working together to learn more about the world.
Science has also been used to control the world. In the last two centuries, we have moved from being simply observers of nature to being, in a modest but growing way, its controllers. Concomitantly, we have occasionally disturbed the balance of nature in ways that we did not always understand. Science has to be watched. Non-scientists can no longer afford to stand to one side, ignorant of the meaning of advances that will determine the kind of world that their children will inhabit – and the kind of children that they will have.

From around 2015, books sales started to decline. This made people question the future of ebooks. Some people thought that ebooks would kill print books. But this is not true. Digital and print books can coexist in the market. The idea of the disappearing book is powerful because it tells us about our fears and hopes for the future. It also tells us about our connection to technology. As technology changes, we often feel like we are losing things that we used to have. This is why entire industries develop around retro products and older technologies. For example, people who like reading books often buy old books or e-readers. This should provide some reassurance to those who still worry about the disappearance of print books.

Every day, I wake up early, brush my teeth, and make coffee. I write about how some of the greatest minds of the past made the time each day to do their best work. I also write about my own daily routines and how they help me to be creative and productive.
I have a lot of concerns about creative work and earning a living. I struggle with how to do meaningful creative work while also earning a living. I also wonder if it is better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day.
I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted similar challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.
This book is about my daily routines and how they help me to be creative and productive. It is also about the challenges of creative work and earning a living. I hope that this book will inspire you to think about your own daily routines and how they can help you to be more creative and productive.

Howard became a palaeontologist because he was interested in dinosaurs. He studied delicate creatures revealed on the surface of grey rocks. He worked on his doctoral thesis and got a job as an Assistant Lecturer at Tavistock College in London. He often found himself contrasting the orderly nature of his professional life with the anarchy of private concerns.

Charles Spence is a professor of experimental psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He has studied how the senses interact to form our perception of flavour. Through his studies, he has influenced what we eat and drink. He has also studied how food is experienced with others.
Spence has written a book called The Perfect Meal, which is packed with insights that are fascinating to anyone in possession of an appetite. It includes information about how much we eat when eating with others.
Spence's lab is un-space-age. It has soundproof booths and stacks of ancient-looking audio-visual equipment. He can afford to work more creatively with cooks because he keeps his overheads low.
Spence is currently helping famous brands through reductions in salt and sugar. He points out that it is in their interests to help loyal customers stay alive for longer.

Our brains are very busy these days. We have a lot of information to deal with, including facts, rumors, and things that are not true. We also do more things than ever before. Thirty years ago, people used to make our airline reservations and help us find what we needed in shops. Now we do most things ourselves. We have smartphones that help us do all this. But there’s a problem with multitasking. It makes us less efficient. Multitasking can increase the production of stress hormones and make it harder to focus. It also makes it harder to make decisions. We can end up making truly bad decisions about something important. To make matters worse, multitasking requires a lot of decision-making. It turns out that making lots of small decisions takes up a lot of brain resources. We rapidly spiral into a depleted state in which we can end up making truly bad decisions about something important.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking up concrete into pieces. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals had behaviours that produced measurable outcomes, and science recorded those outcomes. But recently that has partially changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, and other animals, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. The new research has started a debate about whether animals can be said to have consciousness and conscience. If animals do have consciousness, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding and interacting with what we read or listen to. It helps us to have a deeper understanding of the text or information. There is a belief that argument is a way of finding the truth. Although there’s little debate that information technology complements and often enhances the human mind, there’s increasing concern that the same technology is changing the way we approach complex problems and making it more difficult to really think.
Reading enhances thinking and engages the imagination in a way that visual media such as video games and television do not. It develops imagination, induction, reflection, and critical thinking, as well as vocabulary. However, visual media actually improve some types of information processing.
Many people – particularly those who are younger – wind up underachieving and not making the most of their capabilities. How society views technology has a great deal to do with how it forms perceptions about critical thinking.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing or thinking about how we ought to live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He wrote two books about the benefits of manual trades and philosophy. One of his books is about how to cope with modernity. He was inspired to write it when he was shopping and noticed that advertisements popped up on the credit card machine. He realized that these demands on our attention were becoming increasingly difficult to avoid.
Crawford says that we are being prevented from deciding what we want to be at the forefront of our mind by something that we are not aware of. It is becoming more and more difficult to think or spend time remembering conversations we’ve had. And because everyone is trying to protect themselves from the irritation of constantly being interrupted, we close ourselves off and no longer want to do simple things like chat to strangers.
Crawford's proposed solution has two parts. First, we need regulation of noise and distraction in public space. More importantly, though, Crawford advocates skilled practices as a way of engaging with the world in a more satisfying way.

What do you do for a living? It's a common question. If you're a philosopher, it's a little harder to answer. Philosophers are no different from the masses, but the idea that they have access to some mystical truth or enlightenment above one’s fellows is a misconception. One reason is that philosophers have established themselves as people who judge the activities of others and celebrate intellectual life. Another reason is that the field of ethics has colloquially come to refer to applied ethics – a subfield that explores the justice of particular social practices.

Foodies, gourmands, chefs and others who love food might expect that thinking about food can contribute to culinary pleasure. However, philosophical discussions of food have mostly been about other topics, such as knowledge or pleasure. Sometimes, philosophical conversations about food appear to be about other things, but further examination reveals that they explore deeper points. It is interesting to note the case of the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, who advocated for the pursuit of pleasure and the avoidance of pain. Food is also social and cultural. It is shared with those in our communities and provides us with dining companions and infrastructure. Ethical issues related to food include what we should eat and the extent to which cooking in restaurants and the home differ. Cooking in the home is more inclusive, while cooking for a living has different obligations. Food and dining can also play a role in bridging cultural gaps.

Rob Daviau is a designer of legacy board games. He felt that the traditional board games he had played as a child were no longer entertaining or challenging enough. So, he started to wonder how board games might evolve. Could they have a storyline? Could decisions made in one session carry over into another? He adapted a classic board game called Risk and created a new version called Risk Legacy. Unlike previous board games, decisions made during gameplay had a permanent impact. Players might have to rip up cards, deface the board, or at key moments open packets containing new rules. The games play out over the course of a fixed number of sessions and long-held grudges become woven into the fabric of the game.
Legacy board games were never expected to go mainstream. Nevertheless, most players, like Russell Chapman, loved the concept. They see it as one of the biggest advances in game design for several years. The legacy format draws not only on video games but also the demand for episodic entertainment fuelled by popular TV series.

Once upon a time, there was an octopus named Inky who lived in New Zealand. One night, Inky escaped from his tank and went to the ocean. It was a story that was shared online. The story is fun because it is about animals being like humans. Octopuses are very smart creatures. They can open jars, recognize faces, and use coconut shells as armor. They can also play with other animals.
However, some people think that anthropomorphism is not scientific. They believe that animals are not as smart as humans. This is called anthropodenial. Dr. Frans de Waal is a scientist who studies primates. He says that anthropodenial is not true. He says that animals have many of the same skills as humans, such as the ability to think about the past and the future, to demonstrate empathy, and to anticipate the motives of others.
De Waal believes that we are emerging from a dark period where we thought that animals were not as smart as humans. He says that the times are changing and that everyone is learning to appreciate animal intelligence.

Once upon a time, there was a technology called robotics that has the potential to change the world. Robots have already been used in factories and cars for many years. Now, experts are saying that robots will soon be used in many other places.
Many people believe that robots will take over their jobs. However, this is not true. Robots can do some things that humans can do, but they cannot do everything. They also need human help to service and program themselves.
The development of robotics is creating new jobs. For example, there will be more jobs for technicians and programmers. However, there will also be fewer jobs for lower-skilled workers.
In order to prepare for the future of work, we need to invest in education and training programs. We also need to develop new regulatory frameworks to ensure our safety and privacy.

Because there is a place where climbers can climb, the mountaineer George Mallory said that he wanted to climb Mount Everest. People have a desire to understand why anyone would participate in such a dangerous activity. Climbing can give people a feeling of freedom, but it can also be very confining. There is an apparent paradox in many forms of climbing. Climbing can also help cultivate important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment.
When asked why people climb, US rock climber Joe Fitschen argues that climbing is in our genes. It is inherent in our basic makeup to take on challenges and test limits. Climbing also serves a certain practical value – it may help develop the traits and virtues that allow one to flourish and live well in our non-climbing world.

Alfred Brendel was a famous pianist who played classical music. He was a very intelligent and disciplined person. He wrote and played a lot, but he taught very little. Those who knew him well saw a playful side to his character.
Brendel had a young student named Kit Armstrong. Kit was a restless and impatient young man. He was always learning new things and composing. Brendel was impressed by Kit's ability to listen to his own playing and his sensitivity to sound.
Now, Brendel is old and he can no longer play. But he is still busy writing and composing. He is also helping Kit to learn to play the piano.

My Granddad's garden was a beautiful place. It was on the bank of a river and sloped gently down towards the water. You couldn't reach the river but you could hear the sound of the water and the birds that sang in the trees above. I imagined that all gardens were like this – a place of escape, peace and solitude.
My Dad was a quiet and withdrawn person. He had a lot of phrases that he liked to use, one of them being 'It's immaterial to me'. He was probably disappointed that he hadn't made more of his life. He left school without qualifications and became apprenticed to a plumber. It wasn't something he was passionate about.
I always wanted to like the piano but it did its best to intimidate me. The only thing I did like about it were the two brass candlesticks that jutted out from the front. I'd walk along the river bank looking for a suitable spot where I could take off the painful sandals and leave them with my picnic while I ventured out, tentatively, peering through the water for any fish that I could scoop up with the net and take home.
One day my father announced, 'They've got a vacancy for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.' In one brief moment Dad had gone against his better judgement. He might still have preferred it if I became a carpenter. But I like to feel that somewhere deep down inside him was a feeling that things might just turn out for the best. If I stuck at it.

Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck, a small island in Scotland. The island is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. There is a strong wind blowing, and the waves are high. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, is playing with the sheep. The wind is very strong, but MacEwen is not worried. He is happy on his island. MacEwen is giving me a tour of his neighbourhood. He tells me about the different islands and the weather. He also tells me about his family and his farm. The island life is not perfect, but MacEwen is still happy. He has a lot of good food and a beautiful home.

The game design industry is a competitive one, but it is also expanding. It is not easy to get into, but there are ways to do it. If you are passionate about games and have the skills to make them, you can definitely get involved.
There are a few things you need to do to get started. First, you need to make games. You can do this on your own, but it is much easier if you have some support. You can also take a postgraduate course in games. This will give you the skills you need to be successful in the industry.
Once you have the skills, you need to network with people in the industry. This will help you to learn about opportunities and to get your foot in the door.
Finally, you need to be patient and persistent. It takes time to build a career in the game design industry. But if you are passionate about games and you are willing to put in the work, you can definitely achieve your goals.

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, and I'm grateful that he didn't impose it on me. I had a friend who used to come to the park with me, but he stopped wanting to play and has never been involved in football since. I'm glad that it didn't turn out that way for me. I have worked hard to improve my skills, and I know that with practice, anyone can achieve great things. I also want to help my son to enjoy playing sports. I'm not sure what the future holds, but I'm excited to see what I can accomplish.

It was because of Sam Carter that we were living at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find somewhere cheap for us to live. The beach had been deserted since the warm weather had been blanketed by sea fogs. Reef Point was seldom patronised by the casual day tripper. There were a lot of people at the beach. My father was hard at work trying to write a script to a deadline. I moved out onto the beach, taking a book to read, and Rusty for company. Rusty was my dog. We had a lot of fun playing together. Sometimes though, there were things that he had obviously not dug up – a new sneaker, a bright beach-towel. We had been swimming that day. The sun was setting and it was getting cooler. We sat watching the surfers. They were having a lot of fun. One surfer in particular caught my eye. She had a style that made all the others look like clumsy amateurs. But now she seemed to decide to call it a day and rode in on a final wave.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a queue at the dock in Southampton. The queues were long and there was a lot of people waiting. The atmosphere was not very happy. There was a problem with the computer system and the passengers were not able to get on the ship. Violet was feeling frustrated and she was worried about her phone. She couldn't call anyone because her phone was missing. She was also concerned about her neighbour, Kristina, who had no other means of finding numbers she needed in New York. Eventually, the queues started to move forward and Violet was able to go to her room. She was happy that she had a balcony.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he found a mystery. He was looking for images to use in a book about the history of the Portage Park neighbourhood in Chicago. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Vivian Maier, a street photographer with a keen eye for capturing compelling images. Since then, Maloof has amassed an archive of Maier’s life and work. He has a lot of her cameras, film, prints and negatives. He also has many movies and audiotapes. Maloof is working with his friend Anthony Rydzon to share Maier’s story. They are trying to find out more about her life and work. They have contacted several local families and employees of the shop where she had film developed. Maier was born in 1926 and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and came to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person but she had a strong interest in photography. She always had a camera with her and took pictures of people, children, and the poor.

When a novel is described as ambitious, it usually means that it is not successful. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. The book is set during the 1860s in New Zealand. There has been a series of crimes committed, and a council of 12 men has convened to solve them. The plot is complex. Catton said she set out to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past offered more opportunities for complications and misunderstandings for her characters to deal with. The book is long, but it is also exciting and fun to read. Catton is a talented writer who is passionate about her craft and her home country of New Zealand.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved to play the guitar. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and the bass guitar when he was sixteen. He also built his own guitars.
Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think of it as a career. He was also into painting and sculpture. He chose to study architecture at university, but he dropped out because he was too individualistic. He then decided to make guitars for a living.
Jonny has been making guitars for forty years. He makes a living by selling his guitars and cleaning windows part-time. He says that developing a career is more straightforward today than it was when he started. He also feels that there is no satisfactory substitute for trial and error.

Any conversation about English conversation, like any English conversation, usually starts with the weather. It is a traditional thing to talk about the weather when you meet someone. It is also a way to start a conversation and make people feel comfortable.
There are three specific contexts in which people talk about the weather in English. They can use it as a simple greeting, as an ice-breaker leading to conversation on other matters, or as a default topic when conversation on other matters dries up.
It is easy to see why people of other nationalities, and even many English commentators, have assumed that English people must be obsessed with the subject.

Alice Leader was standing in front of the remains of a Roman wall in Britain. She was explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing feat of engineering it was. She had already stimulated their interest, since the group had chosen this trip above glamorous tours to other countries. But what they really wanted to know was why it was built. Alice felt her answers were unsatisfactory. She decided to write her own novel to add context and human interest to life at the Wall in Roman times. After retiring from teaching, Alice embarked on a second career as an author. She wrote her first novel and was successful.

To raise money for charity, two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, were challenged to take part in a unique race. The race would set man against car and brother against brother. In the Yorkshire Dales of northern England, the brothers would race to the same point. The race started at a beautiful lake and was to finish at the highest road in Yorkshire.
Jonny was driving a car and Alistair was cycling. The race started and Alistair sprinted away on his bike. Jonny jumped in the car and was soon on the road. The next time the brothers would see each other would be at the finish line.
The race was not easy. There were obstacles and challenges. But the brothers persevered and finally reached the finish line. They were both disappointed, but they were also proud of their accomplishment.

The silence on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships is very quiet. You can bounce the ball up and down on the grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the ancient stadium, the players dressed in white, and the respectful crowds all combine to make you feel like you are in a different world. The quiet of the Centre Court is good for your game. It helps you to focus on the point you are playing and to shut everything else out.
The silence of the Centre Court is broken by a sudden noise when a point is done. There is applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. You hear them, but as if from a long way away. You are so focused that you have no sense at all that there are millions of people watching you.
You have always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. If you have the chance to play there, you should take it. It is the biggest tournament of them all. You can win or lose, but you will always have the memory of playing at Wimbledon.

A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in early 1957. She spent most of her life in Africa and became known for her work on chimpanzees. She wrote a book about her research called "In the Shadow of Man." It is still popular today. Jane Goodall helped create a new way to study animals. She also helped change the way humans think about themselves.
There are some things that we learned from Jane Goodall's work. First, we learned that chimpanzees eat meat. Second, we learned that chimpanzees create and use tools. Third, we learned that chimpanzees share with humans a similar set of emotions. Fourth, we learned that chimpanzee communities across Africa possess various distinctive cultural traditions.
Jane Goodall's work has been praised by many scientists. She is considered one of the greatest biologists of all time. Even as a child, there were some early indicators of the person Jane Goodall would become. One day, she crawled inside a henhouse to find out how hens lay eggs. This event showed that Jane Goodall was always curious about the natural world.

During a conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me in different voices. She has a lot of voices that are recognisable to people who have seen children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computerised employee programmes about health and safety. Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. She says that there is more to it than just being able to do funny voices. You also have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices as she watches children’s TV. She also recommends attending specialist workshops and having a passion for human sound.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. It's a dream job that many people have. But most people eventually give up on their dreams and consider more realistic professions. To become a cartoonist, you don't need a lot of money or a university degree. You just need your brain, your hand and something that makes a mark. If you feel that doing anything else would be impossible, then cartooning might be the right job for you. But it's a tough job and not everyone can do it. You need to be patient and persistent. If you're interested in becoming a cartoonist, there are a few things you can do. You can draw, practice your skills, and get feedback from others. You can also find online resources and tutorials to help you learn the trade. With hard work and dedication, you can achieve your dream of becoming a cartoonist.

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and having a clear-out. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had bought me for my 16th birthday. I felt sad about throwing it away. I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of rubbish, when a young man came up to me and asked if I was going to throw it away. I said yes and he asked if he could have it. I gave it to him and felt sad. I regretted throwing it away.
A few months ago, I found out that my guitar had been found. I was very happy. I contacted the person who found it and arranged to get it back. I was so excited to have my guitar back. I started playing it again. I felt like I was playing the guitar for the first time. I also felt like I was learning new things. I guess I'll have to form a band.

There has been a lot of talk about sleep lately. Sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social well-being. It seems that people who have the hardest time sleeping are the ones who most appreciate how important sleep is. Dreams are important too. They help us find new patterns and create combinations that break through our usual habits of thinking.
When you wake up in the morning, you may have forgotten your dreams, but they can still have a positive impact on your day. If you write or create art, you may find that you are able to write or create more easily after a dream. Even if you don't write or create art, you can still benefit from dreaming. Dreams can help you to think creatively and flexibly, which can be helpful in many aspects of life.

It was twenty years ago that Susie Ray left London for a small coastal town in south-west England. She has a studio with a beautiful sea view. There are a lot of empty frames hanging on the walls, between photographs of her two daughters. Susie is a copyist artist who can reproduce the richness of an early-20th-century impressionist masterpiece as easily as the brilliance of a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait.
She has painted the works of numerous great artists, including Renoir, Monet and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so faithful that art experts mistake them for the originals. Her clients include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors save on house insurance by storing the original in a bank safe and displaying Susie’s copy.
Susie has always been open about what she does. She believes doing it badly would be letting the artist down. She also puts her own signature on the back of the canvas. She has no regrets about having done it, but she’s glad she eventually found something more rewarding financially.

During Ellen MacArthur's racing days, she loved the sea more than anything else. She had a special connection with her boats. They worked together like one. When she was on land, she felt that life was not important. Everyone was interested in her racing, and she wanted to be back on the ocean again. After she won a race, she took you into her boat and showed you how she prepared for the race. She talked about the careful planning that had gone into provisioning, how she worked out exactly how many rolls of kitchen paper she would need, and how she looked after her boat.
She also started a charity to help young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. She believes that we all have a responsibility to protect the planet. She wants to inspire others to take action and make the world a better place.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his generation. Young people are spending more time on computers and games consoles, so Jordan hopes to inspire kids to climb their own mountains. He has already climbed five of the Seven Summits and might actually do it before his teenage years are over.
There are some people who think that taking a young climber up the world’s highest mountain is a bad idea. They say that a young climber might have the necessary physical strength, but they doubt whether a teenager would be emotionally strong enough. And they couldn’t see how a young person could have gained enough experience to develop the good judgment and reactions a climber must have in order to take part in such a project safely.
But Jordan’s parents believe that their own experience as climbers will help. They weigh up the risks all the time, but they think that their son is strong and mature enough to handle the challenge. And Jordan himself is motivated by his goal. He says, ‘I just focus on achieving my goal.’

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's probably not classical music they're listening to. Most people can name a few pop groups, but not many know who Brahms was. If you don't know who wrote the music, you are unlikely to own any recordings of their work. Classical music just doesn’t hold much attraction for most people, and that is particularly true of teenagers. There are a few reasons why teenagers don’t like classical music. First, the pace and rhythm of classical music are not easy for us to listen to. Second, classical music is not structurally simple like pop music. Third, the subject matter of classical music is not as appealing to teenagers as pop music. Finally, the way we listen to music has changed. Nowadays, you can find any music you want at the click of a mouse, and yet the sound track to our lives is rarely classical.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. She was going to make her mother sorry she had come. Her mother was getting out of the other door at the time, so she didn’t overhear. Bonnie was going to the riding centre. There was a nice old building where the horses were kept. The horses were very well looked after. Bonnie treated horses with respect. She rode a horse named Maverick. It was a brown horse with a touch of white. The horse was lively and Bonnie liked that. She rode the horse around the paddock. The rhythm was exhilarating.

I met Cody Simpson before. He is a 15-year-old Australian singer. He has already released a number of successful songs. One day, he started posting videos on the internet. These videos changed everything. He began to get a lot of fans. He was very talented at swimming and surfing. But he decided to focus on his music career. He moved to the US to pursue his dream. He is successful now. He says that success comes from a willingness to say 'yes' to your big break, even when it's a little scary to do so.

In the United States, teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents and have part-time jobs, volunteer, and excel in all of these fields. The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US. They have launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space. John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. One of the most interesting things about studying further and higher education in the UK is that students can get involved in research early on. Research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It can also be seen as a way to build knowledge and skills. You can use research approaches and skills in your studies and in your job. As a student, you make a contribution to knowledge. You don't just copy what you read, you make it. Making knowledge is based on asking questions, rather than taking things for granted. You can ask questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? How might that be done? What if this were different? How does it work in that context? What do we really make of whatever facts we are given, views we are meant to adopt, or beliefs we are told about? Why does it matter? These are the most common questions that underlie what we call research.

Cities have always been places where people gather to share ideas and discuss important topics. They can also be very challenging places to live. The modern city is a place of creativity, but it's also a place where people feel overwhelmed and stressed. Scientists have found that cities actually dull our thinking, sometimes dramatically so. One of the main reasons for this is the lack of nature in cities. Studies have shown that people who can see trees from their windows recover more quickly from illness. Natural settings also help us to focus better and concentrate. They provide a break from the constant distractions of city life.
In recent years, it has become clear that city life can have a negative impact on our mental and physical health. It can also make it difficult to concentrate and remember things. However, there are ways to mitigate the psychological damage of the metropolis. One way is to find ways to integrate nature into our daily lives. Vibrant urban parks, such as Central Park in New York, can provide a much-needed escape from urban life.

The mind is a complex thing. It is like a stick that is used by a blind person. The stick is a pathway that helps the blind person to see. It is also a boundary that separates the blind person from the outside world. The mind is like a stick because it is always changing and evolving. It is also a way of connecting with the material world.
The mind is more than just the brain. It is also the things that we make and use. For example, stone objects, body ornaments, engravings, clay tokens and writing systems play an active role in human evolution and the making of the human mind.
The mind is a powerful tool that helps us to learn, discover, and make sense of the world. It is also a way of connecting with others. The mind is a complex and fascinating thing. It is a mystery that scientists are still trying to understand.

Photography has changed the course of civilization and the way we know the world. It has been especially true in the United States, where photography became part of US culture at every level. Historians say that photography is arguably the country’s greatest single contribution to the visual arts. In no other art form has US work loomed so large.
Photography has been appealing because it is a mechanical process that matches a growing enthusiasm for technology. It also brings the wonders and sights of the world into the front room with an immediacy that is breathtaking. And finally, photography is in harmony aesthetically with a tendency towards realism.
If we want to understand a photograph historically, then we need to pay special attention to its purpose and function within a given cultural matrix. Why did the photographer make the image? How did people first see it? And to complicate matters further, the same image might be seen in several places and times and its meaning would accordingly be different for each one.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician, defined psychology as the 'science of mental life'. This definition is still a good starting point for understanding psychology today. We all have a mental life and therefore have some idea about what this means. However, even though the concept can be studied in rats and monkeys as well as humans, it remains a somewhat elusive one.
Psychology is about the mind or brain, but psychologists do not understand nearly enough about its workings to be able to comprehend the part that it plays in the experience and expression of our hopes, fears, and wishes, or in our behaviour during experiences as varied as giving birth or watching a football match.
The endeavour of psychology is much like that involved in solving a crossword puzzle. It involves evaluating and interpreting available clues. Complex interactions are the norm rather than the exception in psychology, and understanding them depends on the development of sophisticated techniques and theories.
Psychology has the same goals as any other science: to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to control or modify the process that it studies. Once these goals have been achieved, it can help us to understand the nature of our experience and come to conclusions that can be applied directly to people’s lives.

In a storehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a museum of failed products. The museum has a collection of products that were withdrawn from sale because nobody wanted to buy them. The proprietor of the museum, Carol Sherry, sees every product as embodying its own sad story. The museum is a viable, profit-making business. It was started by a man named Robert McMath who intended to accumulate a reference library of consumer products. But his collection ended up consisting mostly of unsuccessful products. The museum is a testament to the fact that most products fail. It is also a reminder that we should not be afraid to fail.

Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But does anyone know why? Most of us probably think we do; after all, it seems obvious. But professional sport is changing faster than at any time in its history and much of what we used to take for granted is now open to question.
There are two main reasons why home advantage exists. First, the home team has the advantage of playing in front of their own crowd. This can give them a boost of confidence and make them more likely to win. Second, the home team has the advantage of being able to control the playing conditions. This can also give them an edge in the game.
However, there are some changes that have recently happened that have made home advantage less effective. For example, travel has become much easier and the top grounds increasingly resemble one another in their soulless efficiency. As a result, home advantage has declined in all major sports, but not by as much as one might expect.
There are a few possible explanations for why home advantage should vary depending on the sport. One possible explanation is that home advantage is primarily a team phenomenon and in baseball there may be less team spirit since it is more about individual confrontations between batter and pitcher. Another possible explanation is that the players’ testosterone levels are higher before home matches, which may be connected to some primitive urge to defend home turf against interlopers.

The more I practice, the luckier I get, said Gary Player. This quote is famous and is used by many athletes and coaches. It is easy to see why this quote is popular. There are two main reasons why. First, the quote is not accurate. It is not literally true that the more you practice, the luckier you get. Second, the quote is enigmatic. It is not easy to understand what Player really meant. However, the quote does have a good message. It is saying that if you practice, you can improve your skills.

A recent report found that many children living in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. The reason for this is that these children have been spending too much time indoors and not enough time outside. They have lost contact with the natural world and have become dependent on technology. This is causing a lot of problems for children.
A follow-up study found that most of the children would be happier if they could go outside more. Many adults also talk nostalgically about the freedom of their own youth. They say that it was much better to spend time outside than to be stuck indoors.
However, there are some concerns about the idea of children spending more time outside. One concern is that parents may be too afraid of danger to let their children go outside. Another concern is that children may not want to follow the same model of behavior that adults have imposed on them.

I am a researcher who has a lot of school. I am good at solving problems. But that has little to do with the schooling I’ve had. Most problems in life cannot be solved with a formula or memorized answers. They require the judgement, wisdom and creative ability that come from life experiences.
Play is the natural means by which adults and mammals have always educated themselves. It is also important for children’s development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young. Children, who have the most to learn, play far more than any other young primates when they are allowed to do so.
Play is voluntary, which means that players are always free to quit. If you can’t quit, it’s not play. School has become more onerous: breaks have been reduced, homework piled up, and pressure for high grades increased. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced impromptu games.
If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the horrid trend that has been occurring over the past half century. We must give childhood back to children. Children must be allowed to follow their inborn drives to play and explore, so that they can grow into intellectually, socially, emotionally and physically strong adults fit for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, there are a lot of young people in their twenties who use social media to find work. There are two popular social media sites that are often used for job hunting: Twitter and LinkedIn. These sites offer the chance for direct contact with potential employers. If you use social media for job hunting, you need to be careful. There are a lot of things that can go wrong. For example, you might send a message to the wrong person or write a message that is too long or too informal. If you make a mistake, it could cost you a lot of time and effort.

Newspapers have been struggling in recent years. Their circulation has fallen and they are no longer the main source of news for most people in the US. There are a lot of people who predict that newspapers will go extinct in the next few years. However, there are also some people who believe that old media have a habit of surviving. Newspapers were once new media, and they have survived many other changes in the way people get news. Today, there are a lot of new ways to get news, but newspapers still have a lot to offer. They can provide us with up-to-date information, and they can help us to understand the world around us.

If humans were truly at home under the light of the moon and stars, we would go in darkness happily. Instead, we are creatures who are adapted to living in the sun’s light. We have engineered the night to receive us by filling it with light. This kind of control is no different from the feat of damming a river. Light pollution is largely the result of bad lighting design. It washes out the darkness of night, altering light levels and light rhythms to which many forms of life, including ourselves, have adapted.
Light pollution has a lot of negative effects on wildlife. It affects migration, reproduction, and feeding. It also causes birds to sing at unnatural hours. Denying darkness is futile. It is as essential to maintaining our biological welfare as light itself.
Living in a glare of our own making, we have cut ourselves off from our evolutionary and cultural heritage. We have forgotten the scale of our being, which is best measured against the dimensions of a deep night with the Milky Way arching overhead.

A company recently announced that it would no longer track its employees’ paid holiday time. The company has a lot of employees and provides a variety of services. The founder of the company said that the idea came to him from his daughter. He said that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel comfortable that their absence will not damage the business. However, there are some concerns about this policy. One concern is that it could lead to increased guilt and stress for employees. Another concern is that it could lead to decreased productivity. It is important to remember that employment law exists for a reason. Workers are entitled to a minimum amount of statutory paid annual leave because periods of rest and leisure are critical to their mental and physical health.

Journal-based peer review is a process that checks the quality of scientific research papers. It is often seen as a way to prevent flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. Reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year. Some people think that this is a price worth paying to ensure the trustworthiness of the published literature. However, others feel that the current system is flawed and that preprints may be a better way to disseminate scientific research. Preprints are drafts of papers that are posted online without having been peer reviewed. They bring academics back to what research publication is all about: the rapid dissemination of new results. Preprints also enable, on a global scale, the informal scientific discussions once confined to correspondence between individuals. They could also become an effective outlet for negative results.

When I ask my students what a poem is, they usually give me answers like 'a painting in words.' Their answers rarely satisfy me, or them. One day I asked a group to choose an object and write one paragraph describing it empirically, as a scientist might, and another in the first person, from the point of view of the item itself. The exercise led to much amusement and useful discussion.
A poem is a thing made. Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals or machines. But such comparisons fall apart upon closer analysis. The most productive thing about trying to define a poem through comparison lies not in the comparison itself but in the debate. A poem is a product of writing and rewriting just like an article, story, or novel. It never really becomes what they usually are – a thing created in order to become a commodity.

I bought a metal detector soon after I was married. It was a lot of money then, but I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. I've also found other interesting things, like brooches and coins. They give me pleasure. But the most impressive find was a torc, which is a beautiful necklace of gold and silver. It's the most famous object from Iron Age Britain. I carried it to the car and showed it to my wife. We didn't try it on because it was too valuable. I hid it in our wardrobe and felt anxious. Finally, I carried it into the council office and gave it to the local council. The torc is currently in the British Museum in London.

Sleeping is one of my favorite travel experiences. I love to sleep when I travel, even though I feel a little guilty about it. When I go to new places, I often find that I sleep better than I do at home. This is because I am surrounded by new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of being. When I sleep on the road, I feel like I am immersed in the culture of the place I am visiting. I also remember my dreams more clearly when I sleep away from home. If you are a traveler, you should embrace the joy of sleep on the road. It is an experience that will change your rhythm and give you a deeper connection to the place you are visiting.

The woman was looking in the mirror. She was thinking about a hat for her daughter's wedding. She picked up a hat and put it on. It was a beautiful hat. But it was so boring. Every other woman will be wearing a hat like that at the wedding. This hat will make her stand out from the crowd.
Mia was also thinking about her own daughter, Jen. It was her thirtieth birthday today and they were having a family get-together. She was looking forward to seeing Jen and her other children. She was also looking forward to meeting the friend Jen was bringing with her.
An hour later, Mia had finished work and was going home. She was thinking about her business, Mia's Hats. It was a success. Women came from miles around to her showroom to buy hats. She also started selling handbags and costume jewellery.

Lawrence Okoye is a young athlete who moved from London to Atlanta in the United States. He is training to play American football. Lawrence is still working out the exact responsibilities of his unfamiliar position. He is also trying to qualify for the final of the Olympic discus.
Lawrence has a lot of talent and he is working hard to achieve his dream. He is confident that he will be able to play in the NFL. He is also aware that there is a lot of competition and that he has to work hard to be successful.
After his Olympic disappointment, Lawrence was still able to find joy in his accomplishments. He is proud of his ability to qualify for the final and he is excited about the future. He knows that he has a lot to offer and he is not afraid to go after his dreams.

I was flying east and I woke up to see that it was already daylight. I looked out of the window and saw the landscape below. It was empty and there was no sign of human life. I felt sad. My neighbour woke up and smiled at me. He said hello and asked me where I was going. I explained that I was flying to a city in Siberia called Magadan. He was surprised because there was no road from Magadan to ride a bicycle. I told him that I had a friend who would be riding with me. He was unconvinced. I tried to explain to him that I had a lot of warm clothes and that I was going to be fine. He still didn't believe me. I was feeling hopeless. But then, I had an idea. I wrote a note to my friend and asked him if he would like to join me on my trip. He said yes. We were going to ride across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China. It was going to be a long trip. But I was excited to go. I was going to do something that scared me. I was going to prove to everyone that I could do it.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots race through a series of pylons. They negotiate sharp turns, barrel rolls and loops at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to find out what it feels like to take part. I had to sign two forms before the flight. The first confirmed that I was in good health, the second that I would empty all my pockets. I also learnt that I would have to try to stay orientated throughout the flight. I was told to relax and enjoy the view. Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was told not to touch anything. By the time we were taxiing down the runway, I was ready to fly. I ignored all instructions and I did not relax. The flight was over in 10 minutes.

Doug Allan is a cameraman who films wild animals in cold places. He has filmed many amazing sequences of polar bears in nature documentaries. His perfect temperature is -18C. Allan was born a marine biologist and commercial diver. He learned about survival in cold places through diving. One day, a TV crew turned up in Antarctica to film a wildlife documentary. Allan took the crew to different places and realized that being a wildlife cameraman ticked all the boxes: travel, adventure, and underwater.
Allan has spent a lot of time filming in cold places. He has a feel for it. He says that the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases, or mosquitoes. Wildlife filming is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments.
Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to trek to the North Pole alone and without being resupplied on the way. He made it to the South Pole as well. Now he is back in the Arctic again, preparing for an expedition he says is even more ambitious.
Pen is a skilled explorer. He has to be. This time, however, there is far more at stake. He will set out on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer trek to the North Pole, taking detailed measurements of the thickness and density of the ice. Nobody has ever done this before.
Pen is married to Mary, a horsewoman, who says he has a ‘spine of steel’ and who shares his love of the outdoors. They live in the country with their two children.
Pen is going to be 47 on Thursday. He has done far less training than he’s comfortable with. Why? Because organizational things always seem more urgent.
Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the search for knowledge that drove previous generations into the unknown.

I had a break from my training. I was going to do something else. Being a successful athlete is a special thing. I had the chance to do more writing and TV work, and to speak to businesses and schools. I also entered marathons and triathlons. I was beginning to miss the feeling of rowing, but I still wasn’t ready to commit to the training regime seven days a week. I spoke to some of my rowing colleagues about whether they fancied the race; I didn’t receive any enthusiastic responses. I knew that if I entered the race, I would want to win. I got in contact with Ben Fogle. We spoke about the remaining costs of the race. We felt we stood a better chance than most, but it would still take work to secure it. Of all the ways to earn money as a retired professional sportsman, speaking at business conferences is one of the most profitable. I think if I’m honest, I had concerns over people’s reaction to me doing a race with a TV presenter. I was worried that it would look like I just wanted to be on TV, otherwise I would have chosen a better partner to help win the race. My concerns disappeared over the course of our preparations.

Last year, I moved to the Arctic Circle in Finland to work with huskies. I was young and restless, and I dreamed of seeing the cold and snowy landscapes of the Arctic. I found a small company run by Anna and Pasi, and they agreed to take me on as a husky dog handler. From December to February, there is plenty of business taking tourists out on sled rides. I could join the team for three months, but I knew the work would be long and difficult. I started packing straight away.
When I arrived at the farm, I was handed a pair of boots and turned out into the cold. The dogs were running back and forth, and I was able to join in on the fun. I learned the basics of dog-sledding, but everything else seemed to be very complicated. By the end of my first week, my head was spinning with instructions and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds. But I was triumphant. I emailed my friends and told them I could chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw in the snow.

On that day, Radcliffe ran very fast and won the race. The press was there to make sense of her extraordinary run. Her time was so good that it would have qualified her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Journalists asked her about the benefits of a natural treatment called emu oil. Cathy Freeman, an Olympic gold medallist, had recommended this treatment to heal the wounds caused by a freak accident.
Radcliffe feels that her achievement never really sank in. She can see it must have been a really big deal at that time. She and her team said they weren’t going to set a limit on anything. That was their motto: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage.
Radcliffe began to calculate as she approached the finish line. She knew she could finish in under 2 hours 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She ran very fast and finished the race in 2 hours 16 minutes and 25 seconds.
After the race, everyone wanted to know how an athlete who ran with such an awkward style had beaten the grace and skill of the East African runners. Radcliffe's physiotherapist, Gerard Hartmann, had stayed with her for weeks at a time, providing daily sessions to counter the pain she was experiencing. He says, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists and there was nobody on the treatment table who could ever take that level of pain. She would hurt me rather than me hurt her. She would actually wear me down because I'd have to go so deep into her muscles, I would have to ice my thumbs afterwards I was in such agony."

When I first started a cookery programme called In Search of Perfection, I was not sure how people would react to it. There had been a lot of talk about the food revolution happening in Britain, and I was confident that we had created a series of programmes that made a new contribution to that. I watched the first programme and was relieved that it was successful. The show was a big success and led to many other projects, including a book based on my experiences at the restaurant I own. In each project, there is a sense of being on a journey. I wrote several books in a series called 'Perfection', each one accompanying its own TV programme of the same name. In these books, the journey was often physical, with passports and suitcases and itineraries. The latest book in the series is called 'In Search of Total Perfection'. It is about meeting extraordinary artisans and exploring new foods. Despite the book's title, I knew that I wouldn't be claiming the recipes were perfect. But I thought that, by using my skills and knowledge, I could pin down some of the things that made these dishes work.

We were driving to Marrakech when the van broke down. John got out and opened the hood. He stood there for a long time looking at the engine. He was thinking about what to do. Bea was worried. She said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was big. There was nothing much in it. Just grass and flowers. We sat on the side of the road and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John go away. Mum stretched out on the grass. She told us a story. I told them about the birds. The tea was sweet. We stayed at the café all day. When it began to grow dark, John said, "I suppose it's a miracle it got us this far." Mum made an open-air bed for us in the hotel garden. It was nice to go to sleep on the ground. We followed John into the hotel. It was set back from the road. We sat down in the shade of the terrace. The tea was very sweet. We stayed at the café all day. We followed John into the hotel. It was set back from the road. We sat down in the shade of the terrace. The tea was very sweet. We stayed at the café all day.

Lucy was talking to two other pianists at a party in the hotel ballroom. They were older than her and good enough English speakers. They talked about the pieces they were playing, where else they’d travelled recently, and where they were going next.
Lucy had not wanted to go to the festival, but she had made it. Her dad bought her a necklace and her brother got excited. Her teacher took her out for a special dinner to strategize a repertoire.
In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather turned to her. ‘You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are.’
She did like that part. Being somebody. Even if it meant certain people were jealous or thought she was too young to get the kind of attention she did.

Dad said that spending too much time online is not good for you. He thinks you should get out into the real world. Generally, research shows that teenagers who use social media have a wide circle of real-life friends, a good sense of identity and belonging, and are developing the essential technical skills we need to be citizens of a digital age.
Social networking has become an integral part of modern childhood. Teenagers don’t just consume media like adults do, they inhabit it. It performs a similar function to hanging around at the youth club, as today’s parents used to do when they were younger. It can help you develop your sense of identity, deal with teenage issues and get on with your peers.
If you’re not outgoing or have a specialized interest, social networking can also help you. You can connect with others who share your interests and create your own content. This can be a great way to express yourself and build your employability skills.

When people think of a family vacation, I guess most people don't think of a cross-country adventure through the US and Canada. However, my parents clearly weren't looking to put their feet up as they organized our summer vacation this year. We packed a lot of stuff into the car, including suitcases, coolers, and clothing. We set off on our journey and traveled for many miles. We stopped at a town in Oklahoma and learned the rule of the road: cattle get the right-of-way. We also visited a national park and saw a lot of bears. It was a memorable trip.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Her family was separating for two years. Her father had an assignment overseas, and her mother would be joining him, but Rose and her sister Amy were staying in England. Amy was completing her final school courses and would be living under the guardianship of the college Head. It was her last year at school so it would have been unfair on Amy to move. To Amy’s delight, she had been given the best room at the college, with its own kitchen and study area. Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. It was only vague holiday memories that Rose recalled of her grandmother. She had never known her grandfather. Her parents had not been enthused by the idea of her living with her grandma, but Daisy had insisted that it was no trouble. Rose was sensible and very mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, about keeping fit, and getting enough sleep. But this time Rose had insisted on one thing: she wanted her independence. Living with Daisy would be fulfilling all her needs. But Rose wanted to play music loud if she wanted, and to invite friends over or go out without having to ask permission every time. Surely she could be trusted to do these small things now?

Charlotte Grainger is a young writer who wrote a novel. She started writing the novel when she was 13 years old. The novel is about to be published. Charlotte is proud of her achievement. She knows that writing a book is a challenge, but she was determined to do it.
The book is a good read. It is well-written and action-packed. It is also about a teenager who is going through a lot of changes. Charlotte is a strong and independent young woman. She is not afraid to stand up for herself. She is also a good writer. She has a lot of talent and she is not afraid to share her ideas.

Our instructor, Gareth, told us that speed is our friend, not our enemy. We looked down the ski slope and saw David push forward, skiing off down the slope towards the jump. He hit the approach ramp fast and flew upwards, arms flailing in the air. Something was wrong and we held our breath. He hit the ground and flipped head-first into the snow. Gareth said that speed is an unpredictable beast. I didn’t want to try freestyle skiing, but my parents decided that I would have a winter holiday at a training centre for freestyle skiing in the US. I practised my moves indoors and headed outside to try them for real. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. But I was proud of myself for achieving such an elusive goal.

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster in an amusement park. You come to a stop and inhale sharply. Your stomach is suspended in the air. You hurtle quickly forwards, sharply left, then upside down. You let out a roar of fear. Amusement parks are a huge industry. To deliver the thrills and ultimate-escape-from-reality that guests seek, there are huge teams of engineers and designers. Creating a rollercoaster is a big challenge. It's not just about creating the perfect balance of pleasure and fear while ensuring that passengers are safe. It's also about introducing enough novelty to keep visitors wanting more. The teams behind rollercoasters must piece together a strong narrative, be it a space adventure or a high-paced chase in the jungle, that works with any innovations.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has achieved a lot as a choreographer. She creates works for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances from time to time. She is busy, but she enjoys her work.
As a choreographer, Miranda is in a teaching role. She likes working with young students. They are receptive to exploring new ideas. They are hungry for success, but they don’t yet have a clear sense of their strengths and weaknesses.
When Miranda starts working with a new group, she concentrates on the dance steps. The music dictates what she does. If the dancers aren’t responding well to a particular composer’s music, that can be frustrating, but she still has to find solutions.
Miranda doesn’t believe in attaching herself to one institution. She has to be prepared to adapt the way she works each time she goes somewhere new.
The conversation turns to the recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. The documentary is accurate and shows the hard work and dedication involved in ballet.
Miranda has done a range of work. She is not just a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist. She wants to widen her horizons.

I have a friend who asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that you can see amazing things on TV, but why sit at home on your sofa when there’s so much out there to experience. I guess that conversation gave me the idea for my crazy four-day trip. I made a film that aimed to get people to turn off their television sets. My friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the star of the film. I fixed the sofa and connected it to some cables and seatbelts. I put my luggage on the seats and slept on the sofa each night. Several friends helped me on the trip. It was the longest distance I have ever walked. I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino. You can see the film on my website.

When I read about swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I'd never tried group trips before. My brother was busy, so I decided a group holiday might suit me. The man at the Greek port was curious when I asked for a single ticket. I explained I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining others to swim around the tiny islands. We did a short swim and then it was time for our first proper swim. I was nervous. I’d trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger and I was at the back of the slow group. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to complete this first distance, though, and was delighted when I finally managed it on my own.

**
I like my job as a flight attendant. I have been to many places, like the US and Australia. I work with great people, and I have a lot of time off. Life is always exciting, which makes it a great job for a young person like me.
When I was a child, I went to a boarding school away from my family. I always flew unaccompanied when term began and ended. I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants to let me help give out meals to passengers.
I decided to become a flight attendant because I love to travel. There was a lot of young people at the interview, and many were accepted. We all had different strengths and experiences. I practised what to say before the interview, and I got the job!
I would recommend this kind of work to anyone. There are so many things that make it worthwhile. The free flights I get aren’t top of the list. Most airline staff are incredibly hard-working, and there’s a saying – ‘no-one’s finished till everyone’s finished.’ It’s like a big family – even though we don’t see each other all the time, we’re still close.

**
At the summer camp, I like seeing the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Many children know how to swim and play table-tennis, but rock climbing is new for most of them. Some children feel nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try and they all get to the top. This makes them feel great. We also get children who miss home at the beginning of the week. It's the older children who feel like that the most. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. We tell them they can phone home after lunch and after dinner. Most children are fine in a couple of days and at the end of their week's stay, they all come up to us and thank us because they have had a great time.

Rock the Planet, a musical show, opened in London last year. It was a big show with a lot of talented actors. The actors had to be really good musicians, too. The show was popular and everyone wanted to hear the songs. There was a young actor named Jamie who was in the show. He was very busy and had to learn a lot of new things. But he was also very happy and proud of his performance. The show is on in London for another year, and it is well worth seeing.
